content: Feeling down? You‚Äôre not the only one. A new poll from Gallup indicates that global misery is at its worst since the company began surveying worldwide emotions more than 10 years ago. Gallup‚Äôs annual Global Emotions Report surveyed 154,000 people across more ‚Ä¶ [+3181 chars]
description: Global happiness has been on the wane since 2014, according to Gallup.
title: Global misery is the worst since records began, according to a new poll
fulltext:
Feeling down? You‚Äôre not the only one. A new poll from Gallup indicates that global misery is at its worst since the company began surveying worldwide emotions more than 10 years ago.

Gallup‚Äôs annual Global Emotions Report surveyed 154,000 people across more than 145 countries and established that 2017 was a deeply miserable year, with humans worldwide suffering from sadness, stress, worry, anger and physical pain more frequently than in any previous years.

This means civilization is the most negative it has been since Gallup started its global emotions survey in 2005. The worst misery scores had formerly been jointly held by 2015 and 2016, but last year‚Äôs war, political division and humanitarian crises seems to have pushed people over the edge.

Almost four out of every 10 people surveyed said they experienced stress or worry the previous day. One in five reported anger, 24 percent sadness and 31 percent physical pain. Overall, 2017 posted a misery score of 30 compared with 28 in 2015 and 2016.

Mohamed Younis, Gallup's managing editor, wrote, ‚ÄúCollectively, the world is more stressed, worried, sad and in pain today than we've ever seen it.‚Äù

‚ÄúRegardless of where a country may fall on the Positive or Negative Experience Indexes or where it ranks in terms of specific positive or negative experiences, all leaders need to be monitoring the emotional temperature of the people they lead,‚Äù he added.

The Central African Republic (CAR), where more than 600,000 people have been displaced by civil war and associated outbreaks of violence in recent years, was the most negative country in the world. It took the dubious honor from previous holder Iraq.

Keep up with this story and more by subscribing now

FLORENT VERGNES/AFP/Getty Images

Gallup said the CAR remains so dangerous that it could not interview anyone from certain parts of the country. Nonetheless, its score of 61 was the worst ever recorded by pollsters.

Other particularly low-scoring nations were South Sudan, Chad, Sierra Leone and Egypt. Sub-Saharan Africa generally experienced worsening misery.

But Latin American citizens are enjoying a boon in happiness, according to the survey results, with the region once again ranked as the most positive in the world.

Paraguay scored the highest on the Positive Experience Index, which ranks nations on whether people smiled, felt enjoyment, did something interesting, were well-rested and treated with respect the previous day.

Colombia, El Salvador, Guatemala and Canada came in behind Paraguay‚Äôs contented citizens. Iceland was the only European nation to break into the happiest 12 nations, with Indonesia and Uzbekistan representing Asia.

Younis suggested the survey provides a vital perspective into the human experience, but noted the values must be seen in a long-term context. ‚ÄúOur research over the years has taught us that tracking how people are experiencing their lives is arguably more important than what their overall score is in one single year,‚Äù he explained.

‚ÄúAlthough developments on a national and global level tend to dominate news headlines, capturing the trends of hope‚Äîor despair‚Äîat the individual level provides the most valuable intelligence.‚Äù

content: The iconic yellow sign. The cheap, yet popular food. The lights that never seem to dim, even as hurricanes and natural catastrophes bare down on the communities around them. The late CNN‚Äôs Anthony Bourdain perhaps had the best description of the diner-like re‚Ä¶ [+7943 chars]
description: Craig Fugate spoke to Newsweek about to tell the story of how a morning ritual and observation turned into a nationwide storm indicator used by millions of people.
title: What is the Waffle House Index? This is the true story from the man who created it, Craig Fugate
fulltext:
The iconic yellow sign. The cheap, yet popular food. The lights that never seem to dim, even as hurricanes and natural catastrophes bare down on the communities around them.

The late CNN‚Äôs Anthony Bourdain perhaps had the best description of the diner-like restaurant chain that serves hot meals 24 hours a day, seven days a week.

‚ÄúIt is indeed marvelous. An irony-free zone where everything is beautiful and nothing hurts,‚Äù Bourdain once said. ‚ÄúWhere everybody, regardless of race, creed, color or degree of inebriation, is welcomed. It‚Äôs warm, yellow glow, a beacon of hope and salvation, inviting the hungry, the lost, the seriously hammered all across the south to come inside. A place of safety and nourishment. It never closes. It is always faithful, always there for you.‚Äù

Waffle House is home to one of the most well-known unofficial indicators used by FEMA to measure the severity of natural disasters: The "Waffle House Index." The restaurant chain even has a "Waffle House News" Twitter account and a Waffle House Storm Center. FEMA offers live tracking to show which of the chain's restaurants have closed and which remain open, a feature that will undoubtedly be looked at by East Coast residents in the immediate aftermath of Hurricane Florence.

But the birth of the unusual storm indicator was not on purpose. Former FEMA Administrator Craig Fugate is the man behind the infamous Waffle House Index. He spoke to Newsweek on Thursday to tell the story of how a morning ritual and a casual observation turned into a nationwide indicator used by the government and millions of people to assess storm damage.

As the man who once ran Florida's Division of Emergency Management, Fugate‚Äôs job took him to southwest Florida in 2004 to survey the destruction left by Hurricane Charley. The Category 4 storm made landfall near Fort Myers, causing catastrophic damage for a storm that was relatively small in size compared to other hurricanes. State officials and meteorologists joined Fugate to inspect the damage-stricken region in the days after Charley.

Keep up with this story and more by subscribing now

‚ÄúWe wanted to get something to eat because the day would be packed and didn‚Äôt know when we‚Äôd get to eat again,‚Äù said Fugate, describing their search for breakfast one morning after the storm. ‚ÄúBut there was nothing open.‚Äù

So, Fugate and his crew drove south along the interstate until they came across a Waffle House that was open for business. However, the restaurant only had a partial menu. The power had gone out, rendering some of the products in the freezer unusable. ‚ÄúBut it was a hot breakfast,‚Äù Fugate said. ‚ÄúWe ate and went on about the day.‚Äù

The next morning, Fugate and his crew noticed a different Waffle House near their hotel had reopened. ‚ÄúWe went in there and it was the same deal: Limited menu and it had just gotten power back up,‚Äù Fugate said.

Photo by Joe Raedle/Getty Images

By this time, surrounding counties were requesting state aid from Fugate to help with recovery efforts. He and his team had begun monitoring indicators like school closures, power outages and search-and-rescue operations to determine what areas were in the most immediate need. They provided a color-coded map of the area to give local agencies and the public a better perspective as to where the severity of damage was located and where the state would begin administering help first.

‚ÄúWell, my guys slipped in an image about the Waffle House Index,‚Äù Fugate said. ‚ÄúBy now, we had figured out where the Waffle Houses were closed, which had no power or limited menus, and which ones were open. If they weren‚Äôt closed and had a full menu, you were moving well into recovery operations and it was much more stable.‚Äù

The Waffle House Index became comprised of three color-coded levels: Green, yellow and red. If a Waffle House was fully open and operational, the storm‚Äôs damage was likely minimal in the area. Businesses were reopening and other services were becoming fully operational, receiving a green stamp of approval. If a Waffle House only had a partial menu, it was a yellow warning sign that the area was undergoing problems of possible power outages or lack of running water. Other restaurants were most likely closed and daily life had yet to resume to normal. But if a Waffle House was closed, that was bad news. It meant the area was most severely hit and still struggling to recover.

‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre sending teams into an area of impact and they start seeing damages, is this an area where they need to stop and go to work in, or do they keep going? If you stopped the first time you came across a downed-tree, how do you know you‚Äôre in the most heavily-impacted area?‚Äù Fugate said. "In many cases, the Waffle Houses were one of those indicators.‚Äù

Fugate and his crew determined that if you got to the interstate and the Waffle House was up and running, it‚Äôs most likely not the most impacted area. ‚ÄúKeep going,‚Äù Fugate said. ‚ÄúIf you got to an area and the Waffle House is open but there‚Äôs a limited menu, you knew you had power outages that were compromising freezers. If you got to areas where the Waffle House was closed, that‚Äôs not a good sign. That‚Äôs probably a place you need to start going to work.‚Äù

More natural disasters, including three additional hurricanes that directly hit Florida that year, forced Fugate and his team to travel the state. There was one indicator that came back time and time again that best represented where the worst storm damage was located after a major weather event. ‚ÄúThe one thing that was true for almost any disaster was if there was anything open or got open first, it was a Waffle House,‚Äù Fugate said.

By the time Fugate was appointed as the head of FEMA in May 2009 by then-President Barack Obama, the Waffle House Index "had followed me there,‚Äù Fugate said.

Photo by Ron Sachs-Pool/Getty Images

Fugate remembered responding to a deadly tornado that had torn through Joplin, Missouri, in 2011. The storm had left more than 100 people dead. Joplin's water system had been damaged so badly that there was no water pressure, leaving the entire city's residents and businesses without running water.

But that "always faithful, always there for you‚Äù restaurant chain that Anthony Bourdain admired so much was ready to serve the community. The local Waffle House was still open, and it‚Äôs where Fugate and his crew headed to breakfast. The restaurant had found a way around the water pressure issue to remain open, unlike the various other businesses in the area.

‚ÄúThey were making coffee by pouring bottled water into the coffee maker, and they were serving breakfast with plastic plates and utensils because they couldn‚Äôt wash anything," Fugate recalled. "But it was hot coffee and a hot meal to start the day.‚Äù

When he was leaving the restaurant, Fugate and his team noticed several cars appeared to be parked at the Starbucks about a block away. But when they got closer, they realized the people weren‚Äôt there for the coffee. The Starbucks wasn‚Äôt even open.

‚Äú[Starbucks] didn‚Äôt turn off their Wi-Fi, so people were pulling up to the Starbucks to get access to the internet,‚Äù Fugate said. ‚ÄúBut because there was no water, they weren‚Äôt open."

Waffle House has become a place for residents and first responders to often receive their first meal after a natural disaster, offering a fleeting moment of normalcy for those severely impacted. As those in Hurricane Florence's path begin to recover, the yellow glow of their local Waffle House could likely provide assurance there's a hot meal waiting for them just around the corner.

"Go down to the Waffle House, they‚Äôre making coffee by pouring water in the coffee maker out of bottles of water. It kind of shows you the different philosophies," Fugate said. "Waffle House gets open, while everyone else has to wait for the infrastructure to allow them to reopen."

author: Margaret Hartmann, Benjamin Hart,   and Chas Danner
content: Hurricane Florence made landfall just east of Wilmington, North Carolina, on Friday morning, lashing the coast with a record-setting storm surge and an onslaught of heavy rain and winds. As of Sunday morning, at least 14 deaths have been blamed on the storm, ‚Ä¶ [+10093 chars]
description: Authorities are warning that the greatest danger, rapidly rising rivers from inland rainfall, is now upon the region.
title: Florence: 14 Dead, and the Floodwaters Are Still Rising
fulltext:
A pickup truck is seen submerged in floodwater in Lumberton, North Carolina, on Saturday in the wake of Hurricane Florence. Photo: Alex Edelman/AFP/Getty Images

As of midday Sunday, at least 15 deaths have been blamed on Hurricane Florence, which has moved over the western parts of North Carolina, South Carolina, Virginia, and eastern Tennessee. More than 700,000 are without power in North and South Carolina, and more than 500 people have had to be rescued from flooded coastal areas.

Florence, now a tropical depression, was crawling inland slower than a person can walk on Saturday, and bringing relentless bands of heavy rain as it went. It sped up on Sunday ‚Äî which should help ‚Äî but authorities are still warning that the biggest danger from the storm is now arriving: catastrophic flooding, and possibly landslides, as inland rainfall overwhelms the region‚Äôs already swollen waterways. Life-threatening flooding conditions are expected to intensify in many downstream areas on Sunday and Monday, and communities along some rivers have already been ordered to evacuate. All told, the storm is expected to deposit some 18 trillion gallons of rainwater on seven states across seven days ‚Äî enough to cover the entire state of Texas in four inches of water. On Saturday, meteorologists warned that the region might only be a third of the way through that deluge.

[5 AM Sunday] Catastrophic, life-threatening flash flooding risk today across much of NC, portions of SC, & southwest VA. Additional rainfall amounts of 5-10" inches are expected, which will produce flash flooding, river flooding and possible landslides in the mountainous areas. pic.twitter.com/HpqNjtM4U5 ‚Äî NWS WPC (@NWSWPC) September 16, 2018

Tropical Storm Florence, as seen by the GOES East satellite at 7:45 Saturday morning. Photo: NOAA/NOAA Environmental Visualization Laboratory

The Forecast and Ongoing Risk

Florence was downgraded to a tropical depression early Sunday, and though it has picked up its pace, through Saturday the storm had barely moved since making landfall, traveling inland at only two miles-per-hour. The record-setting heavy rainfall continues to be the primary threat from the massive storm, which as of Sunday morning had the western parts of North and South Carolina. Southwest Virginia was also threatened by floodwaters from the storm starting Sunday.

‚ÄúIt is the water, it‚Äôs the surge, it‚Äôs the rain that effects and can kill you more than the wind can in a hurricane,‚Äù FEMA Associate Administrator Jeff Byard warned on Saturday.

Mesmerizing & horrifying -- relentless intense rainbands NE of the center of slow-moving #Florence (just like with #Harvey https://t.co/330cAb8U32). 48-hour radar loop starting w/arrival of the rain on Thursday, and with many hours yet to come. #ncwx pic.twitter.com/KusrWMumTl ‚Äî Stu Ostro (@StuOstro) September 15, 2018

As of Sunday morning, parts of three states, including almost all of North Carolina, were threatened by dangerous flooding. The region‚Äôs rivers and streams are all continuing to rise, and many are not expected to crest until as late as Wednesday, according to North Carolina governor Roy Cooper. Many cities and towns along multiple rivers ‚Äî the Cape Fear, the Little River, the Lumber, the Neuse, the Waccamaw and the Pee Dee ‚Äî are expected to flood. One hundred miles inland, 7,500 people along parts of the Cape Fear and Little rivers, including some residents of Fayetteville, were ordered to evacuate their homes on Saturday. That evacuation is unlikely to be the last.

‚ÄúMore people now face imminent threat than when the storm was just offshore,‚Äù Governor Cooper said on Sunday. ‚ÄúI cannot overstate it: Floodwaters are rising, and if you aren‚Äôt watching for them, you are risking your life ‚Äî even in places that don‚Äôt typically flood.‚Äù

URGENT: The Lumber River gage at Lumberton West 5th Street is now up to 20.48 feet. This is MAJOR FLOOD STAGE. It is on its way to breaking the RECORD at this location. If you haven't already evacuate away from the river NOW! #NCwx #Florence #FlorenceNC pic.twitter.com/y9MWPAfhqo ‚Äî James Sinko (@JamesSinko) September 16, 2018

As much as 33 inches of rain has already fallen in parts of southeast North Carolina, setting several new state records.

30.58" of rain in Swansboro, NC not only new state record for tropical system, but also new 2-day & 3-day state rain record. It's 3rd state in past year to set tropical storm rain record joining Texas (Harvey) & Hawaii (Lane). Amounts in NC off-the-charts: https://t.co/coyXU9M6sg pic.twitter.com/J4nPePmCU7 ‚Äî Capital Weather Gang (@capitalweather) September 15, 2018

Florence is forecast to move west and north on Sunday, heading over eastern Tennessee, then Kentucky, West Virginia, and Ohio. Many of the states in Florence‚Äôs path have already experienced heavy rains this summer, leaving them waterlogged and particularly vulnerable to flooding. Some waterways in the Carolinas had already seen water levels 20 feet above average.

I-95 North in Lumberton, NC flooded. I-95 Is closed in both directions from exits 13-22. Photo via Patricia Powell. #scwx #ncwx pic.twitter.com/ihbsC6P9pI ‚Äî Ed Piotrowski (@EdPiotrowski) September 16, 2018

About 11 million people live in the areas that have been under storm watches and warnings from Florence, and many meteorologists have made an ominous connection between the behavior of Florence and last year‚Äôs Hurricane Harvey, which swamped the Houston area with the worst rain-induced flooding in American history ‚Äî mostly after being downgraded from a hurricane. A team of climate scientists warned last week that big, slow, extremely wet storms like Harvey and Florence are probably going to become more common as the effects of global climate change intensify. Put another way, measuring extreme storms by their wind speed, as is done with the category system for hurricanes, may no longer be a sufficient way to anticipate their impact. Some have called Florence a category 5 flood threat.

Matt Lineberry looks out the door of his home surrounded by flood waters after Hurricane Florence passed through the area on Saturday in Southport, North Carolina. Photo: Joe Raedle/Getty Images

About 20,000 people had holed up in Red Cross shelters in the region ahead of the storm, after more than 1.5 million people were ordered to evacuate in North Carolina, South Carolina, and Virginia. Authorities are warning those who left not to come back until the danger has passed.

PSA: Random idiots aside, judging people who didn‚Äôt evacuate is shitty. Uprooting for a few days is spendy, and a recent study showed 40% of Americans can‚Äôt even cover a $400 emergency expense. Don‚Äôt be a jerk. ‚Äî shauna (@goldengateblond) September 14, 2018

Florence had strengthened to a Category 4 storm earlier in the week, but was downgraded to a Category 1 on Thursday night. By the time it made landfall in North Carolina at 7:15 a.m., the storm was whipping winds at 90 mph. It was downgraded to a tropical storm later Friday, then again to a tropical depression on Sunday, with winds as high as 38 mph.

The Death Toll

15 deaths have been linked to the storm so far, including ten in North Carolina.

A mother and her infant were killed when a tree fell on their home in Wilmington, North Carolina on Friday.

In Kinston, a 78-year-old man was electrocuted while trying to plug in a generator, and a 77-year-old man was found dead, apparently as a result of being knocked down by strong winds.

In Pender County, a woman died on Friday from cardiac arrest at her home after emergency responders were prevented from reaching her by impassable roads.

In Duplin County, which is inland, three people died after their cars were swept away by floodwaters.

A Florence-linked housefire took the life of a husband and wife.

An 81-year-old man was killed after he fell and hit his head while preparing to evacuate

In South Carolina, a 61-year-old woman was killed when she hit a fallen tree with her car.

The circumstances of the other four reported deaths from the storm are not yet clear.

Dashcam footage from Wilmington NC as Hurricane Florence made landfall. Trees on power lines, and numerous trees in the roads.



Video courtesy: Daniel Whittaker / LSM pic.twitter.com/z5zRsalSTH ‚Äî Eyewitness News (@wchs8fox11) September 14, 2018

‚ÄúOur hearts go out to the families of those who died in this storm,‚Äù North Carolina governor Roy Cooper said in a statement on Friday. ‚ÄúHurricane Florence is going to continue its violent grind across our state for days. Be extremely careful and stay alert.‚Äù

Volunteers help rescue residents from their flooded homes on Friday in New Bern, North Carolina. Photo: Chip Somodevilla/Getty Images

The Damage So Far: Historic Flooding and Widespread Power Outages

Southeast North Carolina has taken the brunt of the storm, with several areas suffering through flood emergencies.

More than 400 people had to be rescued in New Bern, North Carolina, after Florence‚Äôs historic storm surge, measured at 10.1 feet above ground level, forced two rivers from their banks and resulted in the worst flooding residents have ever seen in the coastal town. Some people had to be helped from the attics and rooftops of their homes. The town was still bracing for more flooding on Sunday, as inland rainwater made its way back to them.

Trent Court, Lawson Creek Park & City Hall. #FlorenceNC pic.twitter.com/32biAL6cpg ‚Äî City of New Bern (@CityofNewBern) September 14, 2018

The U.S. Coast Guard says it has rescued five people, and has 43 aircraft responding to the storm.

I think this speaks for itself. Union point in New Bern, North Carolina. pic.twitter.com/1LxtrdCJgY ‚Äî Mark Sudduth (@hurricanetrack) September 13, 2018

Almost a million people had lost power because of the storm by Saturday, but recovery crews reduced that number to around 740,000 by Sunday, mostly in North Carolina. As many as three million outages had been predicted. Tens of thousands of utility workers have been brought into the region to assist.

In Wilmington, where a foot of rain has already fallen, an all-time-record water level was recorded on Friday as Florence made landfall, qualifying the storm as a 1-in-a-100-year weather event.

Flooding next to Cape Fear River in Wilmington, NC #HurricanceFlorence pic.twitter.com/cEY53zR38G ‚Äî Suvro Banerji (@suvCBS) September 14, 2018

President Trump signed a disaster declaration for North Carolina on Saturday, and is scheduled to visit the Carolinas to witness the recovery from Florence in person sometime next week.

This post has been updated throughout.

content: With his third feature, an adaptation of James Baldwin‚Äôs novel If Beale Street Could Talk, Barry Jenkins has cemented his style: lush romance on top, hyper-realistic despair just beneath the surface. The title is symbolic: The film takes place in Manhattan an‚Ä¶ [+5070 chars]
description: In Barry Jenkins‚Äôs work, loss is a given. He lyricizes it and sometimes seems to wallow in it.
title: If Beale Street Could Talk Is Romance on Top, Despair Beneath the Surface
fulltext:
Photo: Annapurna Releasing, LLC.

With his third feature, an adaptation of James Baldwin‚Äôs novel If Beale Street Could Talk, Barry Jenkins has cemented his style: lush romance on top, hyper-realistic despair just beneath the surface. The title is symbolic: The film takes place in Manhattan and not on the Memphis Street where the blues were said to have been born. Beale Street, for Baldwin, is a condition of black life in America, and the story it would tell ‚Äúif it could talk‚Äù is the one presented here: a girl; a boy; an unjust accusation; and a huge extended family full of wildly disparate men and women scrambling to save the boy from the fate of so many young black American men.

Jenkins opens If Beale Street Could Talk with a long, overhead traveling shot of two absolutely beautiful young people, 19-year-old Tish (KiKi Layne), who narrates, and 22-year-Fonny (Stephan James), on the night when they‚Äôve decided to become lovers. It turns out that this magic-in-the-moonlight moment ‚Äî the kind that, in Moonlight, Jenkins transformed into a myth of self-discovery ‚Äî is a flashback, and that Fonny (short for Alonzo) now sits in jail, charged with a rape that he‚Äôs so obviously not guilty of that the prosecutor would be a laughingstock if Fonny weren‚Äôt black and the white cop who put him in a lineup not bent on settling a score.

Jenkins and cinematographer James Laxton‚Äôs palette is rich and warm, its colors deepened by a score by Nicholas Britell that ranges from a distant, forlorn trumpet to a string quartet in which the players dig in as if they‚Äôre having their own dialogue between hope and despair. The close-ups are immense, the emotions archetypal. And then, while Tish narrates, come stark, black-and-white photographs of men, woman, and children surrounded by filth and handled brutally by white cops ‚Äî a sudden chiaroscuro in a film so rich in reds and golds and browns. Baldwin‚Äôs words come at as like a slap:

‚ÄúThough the death took many forms, though people died early in many different ways, the death itself was very simple and the cause was simple, too: as simple as a plague: the kids had been told that they weren‚Äôt worth shit and everything they saw around them proved it. They struggled, they struggled, but they fell, like flies, and they congregated on the garbage heaps of their lives, like flies.‚Äù

Jenkins uses that passage in the film, though he omits Tish‚Äôs rather pragmatic admission that perhaps she ‚Äúclung to Fonny because he was the only boy [she] knew who wasn‚Äôt fooling around.‚Äù But it‚Äôs hard to fault Jenkins for swooning over this cast: the broad-shouldered Colman Domingo with his lusciously deep voice as Tish‚Äôs dad, who‚Äôll do anything to make his family happy; Regina King, her features exquisitely empathetic, as Tish‚Äôs mom, who treks to Puerto Rico on a seemingly hopeless mission to convince her future son-in-law‚Äôs damaged, terrified accuser to recant her identification of Fonny; and Brian Tyree Henry as Fonny‚Äôs big, once happy-go-lucky friend, shattered now after a stint in prison that was, all things considered, shorter than might have been but still a racist outrage. It‚Äôs Henry‚Äôs character who warns Fonny, a gifted sculptor of wood and metal who‚Äôd otherwise have no reason to fear white people, ‚ÄúThe white man has got to be the devil.‚Äù

If Beale Street Could Talk drifts back and forth between Tish and Fonny‚Äôs wondrous expectations before the arrest, and the lonely quest to get the charges dropped once Fonny is inside and Tish is carrying a baby. At times, Jenkins does too much of the work for us ‚Äî he pre-chews the material, which he never did in Moonlight or Medicine for Melancholy. He photographs the white cop who‚Äôs instantly enraged by Fonny as if he really is the devil (and if the devil had bad skin). It‚Äôs melodrama bordering on florid opera. Jenkins‚Äôs Moonlight-jukebox moment comes before Fonny and Tish make love, when there‚Äôs close up of a needle dropping on vinyl: a hackneyed image, however transcendent the music. On the other hand, a montage of customers after Tish gets a job at a perfume counter is overpoweringly eerie. Her monologue climaxes with the arrival of a ‚Äútypical white customer,‚Äù who will spray perfume on Tish‚Äôs hand ‚Äúand carry his flesh to your nostrils and he will hold it there, hold it for a lifetime.‚Äù Jenkins makes visceral the feeling that, more than a century after the freeing of slaves, black men and women feel owned. Tish‚Äôs pregnancy is a near-monstrous reminder of a world in which she‚Äôll be bringing a child into the world and raising it without a father. The kicks are violent, incapacitating.

In Jenkins‚Äôs work, loss is a given. He lyricizes it and sometimes seems to wallow in it. Baldwin‚Äôs novel ‚Äî and Tish‚Äôs narrative voice ‚Äî gives him a means of expressing anger. The absurd reaction to the Black Lives Matter in much of the country (Blue Lives Matter! All Lives Matter!) purposely ‚Äî criminally ‚Äî ignores the slogan‚Äôs reason for being: that historically, Black Lives Didn‚Äôt Matter for Shit. Fonny, an artist who might never realize his potential, let alone be a functioning husband and father, is one example in the story Beale Street tells. The others are encompassed by Billy Preston‚Äôs mournful, ironic rendition of ‚ÄúMy Country ‚ÄòTis of Thee,‚Äù which closes the film and suggests that there is actually no medicine for this kind of melancholy.

author: Olivia Nuzzi
content: By the time I arrived at Bob Woodward‚Äôs townhouse in Georgetown on Friday morning, his latest book, Fear, was already in its ninth printing, with more copies sold on just the first day of its release than there are people living in the city of Washington. Thr‚Ä¶ [+21225 chars]
description: The legendary journalist explains Trump‚Äôs nervous breakdown, when to believe a White House official,¬†and why he isn‚Äôt visiting Moscow anytime soon.
title: Bob Woodward on the ‚ÄòBest Obtainable Version of the Truth‚Äô About Trump
fulltext:
Woodward arriving in the lobby of Trump Tower in New York on January 3, 2017. Photo: Albin Lohr-Jones/Bloomberg via Getty Images

By the time I arrived at Bob Woodward‚Äôs townhouse in Georgetown on Friday morning, his latest book, Fear, was already in its ninth printing, with more copies sold on just the first day of its release than there are people living in the city of Washington.

Through the perspective of his sources, Woodward paints a choppy portrait of the first year of Donald Trump‚Äôs presidency. You may have heard that it‚Äôs not going well, and Fear is here to add to that perception with some behind-the-scenes specifics. For instance, that Trump doesn‚Äôt understand how U.S. trade policy might relate to U.S. foreign policy. Or that when papers are stolen off his desk, he doesn‚Äôt notice ‚Äî and doesn‚Äôt even remember that they existed ‚Äî for weeks. Or that he orders his tweets printed out, so that he can study in analog the metrics of their reach. Or that he called his own attorney general ‚Äúmentally retarded.‚Äù

The book unfolds as a series of stories about the officials and staffers in the administration who, to prevent catastrophes both domestic and international, must expertly navigate their relationship with the president, or hatch plots to distract him or coax him away from his most destructive whims.

Trump has responded to all of this in the most predictable of ways, amplifying the book through his tantrums against Woodward. Since the first details about its contents were published last week, it‚Äôs felt as though Fear is everywhere.

In Georgetown, however, it was literally true: Entering the author‚Äôs home required walking past a stack of the books on the floor. It‚Äôs a warm and colorful place, full of eye-catching paintings and, at this particular moment, lots of people and one medium-size dog. Woodward introduced me to his wife, the journalist Elsa Walsh, and then ushered me into a dining room. Over the course of 50 minutes, we discussed his philosophy and methods. But first, my tape recorder malfunctioned in front of America‚Äôs most famous journalist.

I wanted to begin with the end of the book. You decided to close with a quote, attributed to John Dowd as what he wanted to say to the president.

That he‚Äôs a ‚Ä¶ ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre a fucking liar.‚Äù

Why that quote?

Because in many ways the book and the Trump presidency are about the war on truth. That is evident throughout and that his lawyer who worked with him for eight months, was a supporter of his, felt that he could not insult him and tell him that he was a fucking liar but that was his conclusion. That is documented in the book and the relationship that Dowd had with Trump: ‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt testify. Testify means an orange jumpsuit.‚Äù

I wanted to talk to you about how you decide who is credible. It is difficult for me, sometimes, to determine who is credible, even at the most senior levels of the administration at this White House. Mostly at the most senior levels in some ways.

ÔªøParticularly if it is on the record and public. It is kind of a press release.

I agree to a large extent. But I am curious how you decide who is credible. Because somebody like Rob Porter, he is obviously very present in this book. I won‚Äôt guess about your sourcing. There is a lot to suggest that his character is ‚Äî there is a fundamental flaw there.

ÔªøIn what way?

Well, by some personal accounts he is a very flawed human being. He is allegedly abusive. There is a lot to call into question his honesty.

Say that again.

There is a lot to suggest that he may not be an honest individual, right? So why do you decide to trust somebody like that?

ÔªøWell, I am not going into the sourcing but there are ‚Äî you test it with other people and documents and notes and it makes a big difference when somebody tells you something and you get your hand on the document itself. So because I had the luxury of time, of essentially two years to work on this, not quite, even. Ever since Trump was elected you can cross-check and see.

Is it more difficult to do that with this administration than past administrations?

ÔªøThat‚Äôs a good question. They are all hard to get beneath the surface of the sort of press-release version of what goes on. At the same time, lots of of people, as you know, feel distress and concern and some of the people were willing to talk out of conscience.

In a review, Isaac Chotiner at Slate asked if you were perhaps the last optimist.

ÔªøReally? I have not seen this.

He had a lot of criticisms of the book and one of them is there is this sort of view, a bias towards the people who cooperated, and they are presented in an almost heroic way.

But see, he does not know that. No one knows that except for myself and my assistant Evelyn.

Do you think that is true?

I know it is true.

As a reader, there were a lot of moments in the book that it felt rather obvious ‚Äî when you attributed feelings or thoughts to the person in question. Whether that was Dowd or Gary Cohn or Rob Porter or Reince Priebus or Dave Bossie, where it just seems rather obvious who they are and that they spoke to you.

As you know, people take notes, and as I said in the beginning it either comes from the person himself or herself or it comes from somebody who recorded it right afterwards.

But when it comes to thoughts and feelings, I wonder how you think about how to protect your sources when it comes to that.

Suppose somebody‚Äôs [in a] situation and they come out and tell their deputy, ‚ÄúYou know what I was thinking or what I thought when that occurred?‚Äù It is a common form of expression and if you have got the immediacy and a good source ‚Äî so much of this is time against the problem. You just have to chip away at it and go back and try to get documents, and it is possible if you have time.

Do you like any of these people? Did you find any of them to be enjoyable human beings?

You mean the sources or the people in the White House?

Anyone in the administration or influencing it from the outside.

It is a good question, but I just go way back ‚Äî I filter my own emotions out. They intrude so it becomes very ‚Äî it is like the doctor operating on a patient. Do you like the patient, do you not like the patient? It is irrelevant. It is perhaps a bit cold, but I find that is the best path to find out what happens. If you start saying I like so-and-so or I don‚Äôt like so-and-so ‚Ä¶

well I think, I hope, it is possible to have an impression of somebody, good or bad.

Right.

And then you filter it out. You filter that out.

You try to just kill it so it doesn‚Äôt influence anything.

Yeah.

I wanted to ask you about your relationship with Donald Trump. When did you meet him?

Oh. There was a time in the ‚Äô80s when his book came out, The Art of the Deal. My former colleague, Carl Bernstein, called me up and said, ‚ÄúYou know, this guy is amazing. We have got to go see him.‚Äù And I thought, really? And he said yeah. So, Carl was the driver and we went and interviewed him and there is a tape of it, but we were never able to find it, unfortunately.

Really?

Yeah. It would be an old cassette tape in one of those tape recorders. That‚Äôs when I met him and he keeps referring to it in the phone call where he called me last month. He referred to it. When [Robert] Costa and I interviewed him in 2016 when he was on the verge of getting the Republican nomination, he referred to it. I did not take notes. I was a little, kind of ‚Äî I went along with Carl. Carl has good instincts.

Do you remember much about the conversation or what your impression of him was?

You know, it was Trump being Trump. All confidence and ‚Ä¶ but you know, I am being candid with you: If somebody told me this man is going to be president of the United States some day, I would have paid more attention.

And over the years, did you interact with him again. Did you maintain a relationship?

I think I went down to Mar-a-Lago once to give a speech. But that was 10, 15 years ago.

What do you think, if anything, people do not understand about this book?

In other words, what is my review ‚Ä¶

Review of the reviews.

It‚Äôs very interesting.

I‚Äôm sorry to get all meta on you.

Oh. Well, you know Hugh Hewitt, you know who he is? A conservative, I did an interview with him and he read the book and he asked questions about Page 248 ‚Ä¶ and he said that he thinks it is a shame that Trump and people in the White House don‚Äôt read it, because he said that he saw some positive things in it. He actually said that he would air-drop copies to all the embassies in Washington so ‚Ä¶ if they want to see if this is who Trump is. And he said that, oh, it shows no collusion with Russia. Which is true. And I said that I did not find any, but in the end of the book when Dowd is reflecting on the situation, he says, or he concludes, that he and Trump got suckered by Mueller. Turning over all these witness interviews, corroborating documents and so forth, he concludes that Mueller may have something. I don‚Äôt know that, but I believe very strongly that the answer to the Russian collusion story is in Russia. Moscow. If somebody who is really going to get to the bottom of the root Russian collusion issue, the answer is in Moscow. If I were to go there, I don‚Äôt think I would ever come back.

You think you would be killed?

Yeah. It would be preposterous, given the nature of their regime and how they look at the press and so forth.

It would be preposterous to go there?

Yeah. I think so. Certainly at my age with a family. Maybe if I was 30 and somebody in the CIA was undercover and said, ‚ÄúCome and I can help you.‚Äù But that is unlikely, and I am certainly not 30.

Should a younger reporter take the bullet on that one then?

Yeah. What is the Willie Sutton joke about why do you rob banks? Because that is where the money is. Why do you go to the scene, why do you talk to people that were first hand witnesses, why do you try to get documents? Because that where the best version or the best obtainable version of the truth is. In the case of this, I am not going to Moscow.

This book, I noticed, is remarkably bare bones the way you have reported it. Some of your earlier books there is more scene-setting or character-building.

Well, this is a series of scenes.

Yeah, there is kind of a staccato effect to it all. I was wondering if that was intentional or that is just how it turned out.

Well, if you look at the books I have done they tend to be scenes. This happened, then this happened, and so forth. This is very much in that tradition I think.

During an interview ‚Äî maybe it was with Colbert ‚Äî you recounted how you showed up at a source‚Äôs house and they said, ‚ÄúAre you still doing this shit?‚Äù

Yes.

Why are you still doing this shit?

Well, as you know, I have always thought that if somebody came from Mars and spent a year in the United States and then went back and said, who are the people that have the best jobs. [It‚Äôs] the reporters. We get to do interesting things, we get to make momentary entries into people‚Äôs lives when they are interesting and then get the hell out when they cease to be interesting. Hope Hicks is still interesting, but not as interesting as when she was working in the White House.

Okay, if that‚Äôs what you think.

Well, I think because I am interested in what happens, how decisions are made. That doesn‚Äôt mean that she would not be a useful path to information now.

It is interesting you phrase it that way. When you look at these people who work there or who have worked there, do you view them as paths to information or do you try to understand them as human beings?

Well, what drives them and so forth obviously is important, but my aim is to find out what happened. That‚Äôs what we need. Suppose we knew everything that happened in the Trump White House. Suppose there was a tape recorder and a video of Trump every minute.

He would love that.

Well, it would be illuminating, right? The term Carl Bernstein and I developed a long time ago is ‚Äúthe best obtainable version of the truth.‚Äù There has been a lot of reporting on the lies, the things that are untrue. But the question is, what are the consequences of those things that are untrue. How does Trump make decisions? As you go through the book ‚Äî it is all immense new amounts of detail about North Korea, about Afghanistan, about the Middle East, taxes, immigration, trade issues ‚Ä¶ that is what affects people.

Do you think there is more emphasis on the why than the how?

No. I think there has been superb reporting, but there is a lot of new material I have about, say, Afghanistan. The meetings and Mattis finally saying to the president, ‚ÄúWe need to know if the commander-in-chief is with us. We can can‚Äôt fight a half-assed war anymore.‚Äù Very illuminating about Trump and Mattis and the process and what was eventually decided to do in Afghanistan.

I am curious if you believe that objectivity is achievable.

Never pure objectivity, of course. But you can improve on it.

Is it desirable to you?

I have said this before as I have done all these interviews ‚Äî people in our business have become emotionally overwrought by Trump. And I can understand that, but that is not our job. Our job is to figure out what happened, and I think it is very important to be cool about it. That does not mean that you don‚Äôt care or you are not engaged. It certainly is not politicized. I have been accused of being on the left or on the right, and somebody actually called me an ‚Äúultracentrist.‚Äù

Since the election, there seems to be an expectation from the opposition to the president that journalists should do something about the way things turned out. There‚Äôs expectation for journalists to be activists. I‚Äôm wondering if you feel that as well.

I think that‚Äôs not our job. I think there‚Äôs been too much ‚Äî or the appearance of ‚Äî partisanship. Ken Burns, the documentarian, we talked some time ago, and he said, ‚ÄúYou will have written books or done reporting on 20 percent of the presidents that we‚Äôve had.‚Äù And that‚Äôs a lot of time in history from Nixon to Trump, and there is always a climate of opinion about politics and the press. I‚Äôm pretty convinced it‚Äôs important to learn to contain yourself emotionally. You asked the question, ‚ÄúDo I like some of the people in the ‚Ä¶‚Äù I have to say that‚Äôs the first time I‚Äôve been asked that question ‚Äî and I‚Äôve never thought of it. Because I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs relevant. And I‚Äôm sure if I had a psychiatrist who could ‚Ä¶ ‚ÄúDo you like so and so or,‚Äù we could dig into that. But it‚Äôs not ‚Ä¶ You know obviously I repeat myself on this, I just think that‚Äôs ‚Ä¶ I never thought about it.

What I meant by that was not, like, do you want to hang out with them on the weekend. But more do you think they are decent people?

Decent people. Truth-tellers.

I think if you feel that somebody is a decent person coming from a good place, or at least not coming from a bad place ‚Ä¶ I mean that has something to do with whether or not you can take them seriously as a source, a credible source. Right?

A series of interesting questions.

I feel as though sometimes I‚Äôm checking the account of a White House official who is a known liar against another White House official‚Äôs account, and they are also a known liar. And it‚Äôs like, well, what do you do?

This is the zoo without walls.

An iconic quote. Right?

Yeah. And that‚Äôs a zoo without walls and what does he say ‚Äî if you have a rat and a mole and a this and a that and so forth.

And a seal ‚Ä¶

That‚Äôs pretty vividly descriptive and important, and if you‚Äôve got people you can‚Äôt trust, then you go elsewhere. But I‚Äôm not going to spend a dozen hours or a couple of dozen hours as I did with some people involved without having a trust. And it‚Äôs not as you say one White House official who doesn‚Äôt tell the truth and another White House official ‚Ä¶ I think you can penetrate under that for something like a book.

We‚Äôve got internet culture driving impatience ‚Äî give it to me now. Tell me. You get something and somebody will say, Well, can we get it on the website at noon? And the answer is no. [Laughs.] And so, in writing a book, you have to kind of withdraw from the process of the daily news coverage ‚Äî which I love and have immense respect, reverence for ‚Äî in order to keep working the case and the specific scenes and information and finding people and going to see them and staying in their home. It helps to get in their home. People feel more confident in their home. ‚ÄúDo you have any documents?‚Äù ‚ÄúNo.‚Äù ‚ÄúAny notes?‚Äù ‚ÄúNo.‚Äù Well, nobody‚Äôs ever worked in the White House that didn‚Äôt take something home. And then on the third visit, you say, any documents really, you know, would help. ‚ÄúWell, let me go upstairs and see.‚Äù And then coming down, literally, [with] two boxes. And from zero documentation to two boxes. Now those are the moments you feel good about the process ‚Äî which is a process of delay, patience, and trust, and people know I still work for the Post and they see it doesn‚Äôt appear in the paper.

I have a kind of minor logistical question for you. So in your conversation with the president out there, you‚Äôre talking about your process by which you request an interview with him. You say you went to Kellyanne [Conway], you went to Raj Shah. You went through Lindsey Graham.

And three other people which we never got to.

I was just curious: Did you try to go through the regular channel of requesting it through Sarah Huckabee Sanders. Not that it‚Äôs so easy.

Yeah, I‚Äôve tried even Lindsey Graham, which is the one he acknowledged, though Kellyanne kind of acknowledged.

Kellyanne said she didn‚Äôt bring the request directly to him, correct?

Yeah, yeah.

But she‚Äôs ‚Ä¶

And he said, ‚ÄúYou should have told me!‚Äù And ‚Ä¶ then he said, ‚ÄúPeople are afraid.‚Äù That‚Äôs the title of the book. [Laughs.]

It could have been called ‚ÄúPeople Are Afraid.‚Äù

Well, it could have been called lots of things. But that‚Äôs out of his mouth about ‚Ä¶

That interview. One more question ‚Ä¶

Sure.

I was curious what you thought of Fire and Fury. You referenced it in the book, but ‚Ä¶

Yeah. I think, just a different style and it got some of the sociology right about the relationships but there ‚Ä¶ the scenes that are with Roger Ailes or with Rupert Murdoch. It‚Äôs basically devoid of the decision-making and process matters. And sometimes there‚Äôs a process, sometimes there‚Äôs not a process, which I try to describe. And I thought that, you know, that was not the focus of his book.

Did you find it to be a credible book?

I mean, as they say, I think it got the sociology largely right. The relationships and so forth. But 50 years from now what‚Äôs going to be important about the Trump presidency is what he does or doesn‚Äôt do. And if I‚Äôm right, as I believe I am, it‚Äôs a nervous breakdown.

What does that mean? Do you use that phrase ‚Ä¶

Exactly what‚Äôs on display there, nervous breakdown. Things are not connected. There is not ‚Ä¶ there is impulse, decisions. I think that the most ardent Trump supporter could read the book and not feel comfortable about the management and the staying the course. There‚Äôs not a team. You know, it‚Äôs a team of predators, or people who just disagree with the president.

How did you decide to describe it as a nervous breakdown? I was speaking yesterday to someone who is very close to the president and a strong supporter of his, and they were taking issue with that phrase. And I was curious because it is a divisive way of explaining the book.

I think it‚Äôs accurate. And I think it‚Äôs demonstrated.

Is that your assessment or did it come from somebody else in your reporting?

No, no, this is kind of what I got. What‚Äôs the summary here? Nervous breakdown.

Does that not imply that there was a time when it was not broken down? When the Trump presidency was not in disarray the way it is according to your book?

I‚Äôm describing what happened. At first, I think it covers the first 15 months of his presidency. And I think it‚Äôs an accurate summary. Time and time again, you know, John Kelly puts out these memos: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre going to have a process, no more seat-of-the-pants decisions, everything has to be ‚Ä¶‚Äù [Laughs.] You‚Äôre smiling, because you‚Äôve covered the White House. And that ‚Äúwe will have a formal decision memo, signed on everything,‚Äù and then time and time again, the president goes off ‚Ä¶ calling the steel executives and deciding we‚Äôre imposing tariffs. Steel tariffs! Which [to] everyone but Peter Navarro and Wilbur Ross ‚Ä¶ makes no sense.

There were times that I was reading it where I thought that I don‚Äôt know if I would necessarily trust the principal who appeared to be telling you something. That was mostly with the campaign stuff ‚Äî but I‚Äôm not going to explain reporting to you.

A number of people have said they‚Äôve heard some of these things off the record. Of course that‚Äôs the technique people use: ‚ÄúOh, that‚Äôs off the record, we‚Äôre going to seal it away,‚Äù and not let the public know. And people would say, I want to say this off the record. I said no. No off the record.

I think reporters have been so liberal in granting anonymity that officials are shocked when you say no. Did you find that?

Yeah. But not shocked ‚Äî but would then tell anyway.

Yes!

And be background so I could use it.

They don‚Äôt put up a fight.

But see then, this isn‚Äôt anonymity. This is really the source is confidential but the information and the players are not. So it‚Äôs ‚Ä¶

Anonymity, even if they‚Äôre not removing themselves from the scene ‚Ä¶

Well, it‚Äôs the wrong word. Because it suggests to people, oh, maybe the reporter doesn‚Äôt even know.

Well, people are stupid, though, right?

No, no, I think people are actually smart.

Wow, really?

Yeah!

Interesting.

I think so. And it‚Äôs part of the optimism. I need to go, I‚Äôm sorry ‚Äî you‚Äôre nice to come by.

description: A love letter to fashion designers, illustrated by Samantha Hahn.
title: New York Fashion Week in Watercolor
fulltext:
Illustration: Samantha Hahn

The simple presence of an illustration is a much-needed reminder to pause, look, think, and look again. I‚Äôve done illustrative coverage of New York Fashion Week since 2012. In that time, I‚Äôve watched technology transform the industry and its media coverage. Designers livestream their shows. Fashion editors post to Instagram directly from their seats. Fashion has accelerated. That said, fashion is an art form. Art deserves time, space, and context to be fully appreciated.

To me, an illustration reveals the essential, the emotional and aesthetic core, and subtracts the extraneous. It captures the mood and highlights the easily overlooked details of color, texture, and silhouette that elevate a truly remarkable piece of clothing. In a sea of runway images and publicity photographs, I think of an illustration as a love letter, an homage, a celebration of a design that goes far beyond ‚Äúdocumenting‚Äù a look.

Every day of New York Fashion Week, artist Samantha Hahn painted a beautiful moment from the runways. Scroll to see all of her illustrations from the week.

author: Ruth Spencer
content: Before anyone knew anything else about him, it was charm that made Jian Ghomeshi a big deal. It began in the mid 2000s, when he hosted a Canadian arts-and-culture radio show, Q. In one episode, the actor Billy Bob Thornton was a guest, and a singularly obnoxi‚Ä¶ [+6961 chars]
description: It‚Äôs exactly what his new essay is trying to make us forget.
title: What I Know About Jian Ghomeshi
fulltext:
Photo: George Pimentel/WireImage

Before anyone knew anything else about him, it was charm that made Jian Ghomeshi a big deal. It began in the mid 2000s, when he hosted a Canadian arts-and-culture radio show, Q. In one episode, the actor Billy Bob Thornton was a guest, and a singularly obnoxious presence; but in the face of his monosyllabic answers and looks of blank hostility, Ghomeshi retained his composure and his warmth. Eventually, the actor accused Canadians of being boring audiences, like ‚Äúmashed potatoes without the gravy,‚Äù and Ghomeshi gently pushed back, replying: ‚ÄúOh we‚Äôve got some gravy up here.‚Äù The YouTube clip, of this good-natured radio host defending his country‚Äôs honor against a discourteous megastar, went viral, cementing Ghomeshi‚Äôs place as a national icon and skyrocketing Q‚Äôs popularity. And so when, five years later, in the course of an onslaught of sexual allegations against him, the public discovered that behind the scenes of their beloved show, Ghomeshi was allegedly telling his producer he wanted to ‚Äúhate fuck‚Äù her and terrorizing his staff, the sense of disjunction was severe. ‚ÄúCaptain Canada,‚Äù as he sometimes called himself, had turned out to be an alleged monster.

Canadians felt betrayed; Ghomeshi‚Äôs whole thing was that he was the nicest guy you knew. And that‚Äôs why the rumors about him choking, slapping, and abusing women circulated for so long before gaining real traction. It‚Äôs also why his essay in the latest edition of The New York Review of Books is so dangerous. The ‚Äúnice guy‚Äù we once knew is being given the opportunity to repaint himself as just that.

I know what it‚Äôs like to fall for his charm. He and I first met in spring 2010, when we began a brief relationship. (I‚Äôve previously written about what it was like to date him.) At first, his behavior seemed romantic. He‚Äôd drop by my apartment and surprise me, text me in the morning to tell me that he was thinking of me throughout the show. He took me to concerts and premieres. I was 24 and dating a celebrity 19 years my senior and I was enthralled. Everywhere we went people would come up to talk to him like they knew him. With them, Ghomeshi would be like the guy they heard on the radio show ‚Äî affable, friendly, familiar. I loved watching the effect he‚Äôd have on people just by shaking their hand.

But the longer I was with him, the more he became something else. He would demand that I show him effusive public affection and get sulky if I said I was uncomfortable. He exploded at me if I changed our plans. One night, when we were kissing good-bye in his car, he pushed me up against the window so hard it hurt and wouldn‚Äôt let go until I struggled away from his hands.

In what the NYRB has cutely titled ‚ÄúReflections from a Hashtag,‚Äù Ghomeshi reflects on what it‚Äôs like to go from being a celebrity to an ‚Äúoutcast.‚Äù He describes the depression, self-loathing, and professional consequences he‚Äôs experienced since 2014, when multiple women alleged that he‚Äôd subjected them to physical and sexual violence. (The case eventually went to trial, where Ghomeshi faced four counts of sexual assault and one count of overcoming resistance by choking, but was ultimately acquitted.) In the four years since the trial concluded, Ghomeshi recounts being abandoned by his closest confidants, contemplating suicide. ‚ÄúThere has indeed been enough humiliation for a lifetime,‚Äù he writes.

The essay could be considered part of a genre that‚Äôs recently emerged, in which men who have been exposed by the #MeToo movement attempt to return to the spotlight by throwing themselves pity parties in the country‚Äôs most prestigious publications. On Wednesday, John Hockenberry, another disgraced radio host, published a similar piece in Harper‚Äôs titled ‚ÄúExile.‚Äù Hockenberry denies the sexual allegations that were brought against him late last year, and describes the grand injustices that he feels the #MeToo movement has wrought. The question of how ‚Äúexiled‚Äù either of these men really are, considering national magazines are granting them space to tell their story, is certainly worth considering.

In 2014, it took months for reporter Jesse Brown of the Toronto Star to gather all of the horrific, twisted allegations against Jian Ghomeshi. In the end, more than a dozen women came forward with stories of him slapping, choking, punching, and biting them without consent. Two of the women said that before he abused them, he introduced them to a stuffed bear in his bedroom and asked them to turn him around, saying that ‚ÄúBig Ears Teddy shouldn‚Äôt see this.‚Äù Ghomeshi doesn‚Äôt address any of that in his piece. Instead, he qualifies his treatment of women as being ‚Äúemotionally thoughtless‚Äù and admits that he should have ‚Äúrespected‚Äù women more. It seems he‚Äôd like us to think of him as just your average selfish dude ‚Äî the kind of guy who might not return a text or a phone call. I wonder what the woman who said he punched her so many times she couldn‚Äôt see straight would say to that.

Ghomeshi denies the allegations brought against him. In any case, his essay isn‚Äôt really about the the claims, or the women who made them, at all. He spends his pages reflecting on his own pain, without considering the damage he‚Äôs done. He‚Äôs so self-obsessed, he can‚Äôt even bring himself to apologize to the women he‚Äôs hurt. ‚ÄúIn a maelstrom of confusion, humiliation, resistance, and conflicting feedback from those around you,‚Äù he writes, ‚Äúhow much can anyone really inhabit ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry‚Äù? Has he contacted any of the women who he allegedly abused? Has he done any kind of real, measurable work to understand what went wrong? No. This is nothing more than an expression of one man‚Äôs ego.

In about 3,400 words, if you care to read them all, Ghomeshi does his best to remind us how likable he is, that underneath all that ‚Äúsexual assault‚Äù nonsense he‚Äôs still the charming guy we know and love. Most notably, anecdotes of recent interactions with women bookend the piece. In the opening scene at a karaoke bar, he befriends a woman who‚Äôs initially skeptical of him. ‚ÄúChalk up one more human being who no longer thinks I‚Äôm a creep,‚Äù he writes, clearly chuffed at his success. The essay concludes with a woman he meets in Paris thanking him for a great conversation. Throughout the piece Ghomeshi cites the ‚Äúfemale friends‚Äù who‚Äôve stood by him. Look, the ladies love me! he seems desperate to convey.

Eight years ago, the more I got to know Ghomeshi, the more I realized that something didn‚Äôt feel right. But I was so caught up in who I thought he was that I didn‚Äôt want to let go. There were two Jians ‚Äî one in public and one in private. I see much of this same behavior in his essay. An attempt to mask what‚Äôs beneath; a desire to control the experience of engaging with him. This time, his manipulations exist between the lines. This piece ‚Äî which, by the way, only exists because he chose to write it ‚Äî is his chance to tell the story he wants us to believe. It‚Äôs his attempt to try to blind us into accepting his version of truth, without acknowledging the depth of the pain he‚Äôs caused. But we already know who Jian Ghomeshi is, and it‚Äôs not the man portrayed in The New York Review of Books. Make no mistake: This essay is not a reckoning. It‚Äôs just another charm offensive.

author: Sarah Weinman
content: One result of my publishing a book about the real-life case that inspired Lolita, the 1955 novel by Vladimir Nabokov that continues to shock and disturb more than 60 years after its publication, is that people feel compelled to share their opinions about the ‚Ä¶ [+4949 chars]
description: He gets Nabokov‚Äôs novel all wrong.
title: Quit Using¬†Lolita¬†To Absolve Your Guilt, John Hockenberry
fulltext:
John (picnic, lightning) Hockenberry. Photo: Chris Bonanos/Getty Images

One result of my publishing a book about the real-life case that inspired Lolita, the 1955 novel by Vladimir Nabokov that continues to shock and disturb more than 60 years after its publication, is that people feel compelled to share their opinions about the novel. They tell me they love it, they loathe it, they are disturbed by it, they want to explain it. Those are reactions I expected, and planned for.

More surprising, though, is the number of people ‚Äî men, usually ‚Äî who tell me how guilty they feel about reading Lolita, that they once failed to see what it was really about. That they didn‚Äôt see Dolores Haze, the 12-year-old girl the novel‚Äôs narrator, Humbert Humbert, nicknames ‚ÄúLolita‚Äù, as a victim but instead as a seductress. That they failed to see how the real-life case, the 1948 kidnapping of 11-year-old Sally Horner, was directly referenced in the text, and a key influence for Nabokov.

Those men are far from alone. Humbert Humbert is one of the most notoriously unreliable narrators in literature. His description of his monstrous obsession with pre-pubescent girls, whom he characterizes as ‚Äúnymphets‚Äù, is to fool the reader into going along with his criminally skewed worldview. Nabokov‚Äôs dazzling, inventive language overrides the ugly truth that Humbert is a pedophile who rapes 12-year-old Dolores Haze repeatedly over a nearly two-year cross-country odyssey. It is all too easy to take Humbert at his narrative word that young Dolores initiated their sexual relationship, that her wish to lose her virginity justified his illicit (and illegal) desires. There is no reason to trust him. But the last 60 years have shown that millions of readers of all stripes and designations do trust Humbert, and buy into the notion that Lolita is a universal love story.

Which is why it was particularly baffling for me to read John Hockenberry‚Äôs Harper‚Äôs essay. Hockenberry, the longtime host of PRI‚Äôs The Takeaway, did not have his contract renewed in 2017 after multiple co-workers and contributors came forward with stories of sexual harassment and workplace abuse. Hockenberry‚Äôs dismissal from PRI happened during the first wave of #MeToo reckonings that followed the Harvey Weinstein revelations. His public return, through the highly prestigious platform offered by Harper‚Äôs, occurred as his sexual misconduct brethren attempted comebacks of their own ‚Äî including the surprise stand-up set by the comedian Louis C.K. and the Canadian musician and radio host Jian Ghomeshi‚Äôs own self-serving apologia in the New York Review of Books.

That Hockenberry waited barely a year to write his essay is in keeping with the consensus impatience of these so-called canceled men and their collective inability to admit, let alone comprehend, how their behavior harmed women. But Hockenberry wasn‚Äôt satisfied to follow the usual narcissistic playbook. He had to bring Lolita into it.

The novel was part of Hockenberry‚Äôs ‚Äúsmall personal canon of works and experiences that I have had to or chosen to reexamine.‚Äù With respect to Lolita, at least, his initial and concluding judgments betray skewed thinking. Saying that he ‚Äúbecame completely certain that Nabokov would have been arrested if it were published today‚Äù misses the point, because Lolita is so wholly rooted in post-World War II America, with its narrative set between 1947 and 1952, that it could not exist as a contemporary novel. Those who have tried to update Lolita, like John Colapinto with Undone, found an audience indifferent at best, with sales to match.

The most galling part of Hockenberry‚Äôs re-examination of Lolita is his ultimate conclusion: that he found himself ‚Äúidentifying with Lolita, her innocence lost along with any identity other than sexual‚Äù because he, like Dolores Haze, had ‚Äúnowhere to go.‚Äù That a man fired for repeated sexual harassment, one who could hardly wait before jumping back into the public fray, aligns himself with the victim of repeated horror demonstrates a stunning lack of understanding ‚Äî and shame. Whatever Hockenberry lost paled in comparison to the losses of the women he harassed and humiliated. Whatever humiliations he felt don‚Äôt deserve to be discussed in the same sentence as rape.

I would imagine, too, that Hockenberry‚Äôs identification would mortify the Nabokovs. As Vladimir‚Äôs wife, V√©ra, wrote in a diary note days after the American publication of Lolita in 1958, ‚ÄúI wish, though, somebody would notice the tender description of the child‚Äôs helplessness, her pathetic dependence on monstrous HH, and her heartrending courage all along.‚Äù

Sixty years later, more people are noticing what V√©ra hoped for. But the flip side is that more people, particularly men, are clinging to Lolita to absolve their own terrible behavior. Dolores Haze is not a therapy animal. Feeling guilty about the trauma of girls and women doesn‚Äôt absolve you of your own bad deeds and thoughts.

And as more #MeTooed men step forward to reclaim what they felt they were always entitled to, let‚Äôs keep the focus on those they harmed, who always mattered more ‚Äî and always will.

Sarah Weinman is the author of The Real Lolita: The Kidnapping of Sally Horner and the Novel That Scandalized the World (Ecco).Ôªø

author: Craig Jenkins@CraigSJ
content: The Duluth, Minnesota, indie rockers Low have been crafting delicate, icy, minimalist guitar music for 25 years. They weren‚Äôt the first on the scene in the early ‚Äô90s ‚Äúslowcore‚Äù boom, where bands like Codeine, Ida, and the Red House Painters whittled arrangem‚Ä¶ [+5899 chars]
description: Twenty-five years in, they‚Äôve still got it.
title: Finding Beauty in Low‚Äôs Unsettling Machine Blues
fulltext:
Photo: Shelly Mosman/Sub Pop Records

The Duluth, Minnesota, indie rockers Low have been crafting delicate, icy, minimalist guitar music for 25 years. They weren‚Äôt the first on the scene in the early ‚Äô90s ‚Äúslowcore‚Äù boom, where bands like Codeine, Ida, and the Red House Painters whittled arrangements down and decelerated rock‚Äôs hard charging pace to a crawl, but they have outlasted most of their peers thanks to the bond shared by co-founders Alan Sparhawk and Mimi Parker, childhood friends, spouses, and parents to two teenagers. Low perseveres because Alan and Mimi aren‚Äôt afraid to torch the formula and draft a new one. 2001‚Äôs Things We Lost in the Fire worked hard to sweeten the chilly austerity they‚Äôd built up over early albums like Long Division and I Could Live in Hope; 2005‚Äôs divisive The Great Destroyer ramped up the volume and tempo, at the cost of coming out alarmingly conventional. 2015‚Äôs Ones and Sixes came to life at Bon Iver mastermind Justin Vernon‚Äôs hometown April Base Studio in Wisconsin with 22, A Million collaborator BJ Burton as producer. Sixes flipped the script again, adding tasteful synth textures to the three-piece‚Äôs gossamer mix without upsetting the balance. Low‚Äôs puckish early objective was confronting midwestern grunge audiences with the sound of silence, and they continue to find new ways to challenge and confound their base.

This week‚Äôs Double Negative, another Burton collaboration crafted at April Base, is a new metamorphosis. The electronic accents of Ones and Sixes are the main pulse now; the conversion from pleasing, patient guitar, bass, and drum songs to the ambient drones and forbidding borderline noise is a shock on par with the Japanese director Shinya Tsukamoto‚Äôs seminal body horror film Tetsuo: The Iron Man, where a man commits a crime and wakes up to discover his body slowly turning into metal. Double Negative is also a commentary on human cruelty and terror; asked what the title refers to in a recent interview with The Wire, Sparhawk said, ‚ÄúThere are negative things going on, and we‚Äôre reacting negatively.‚Äù The new songs came together after the 2016 election, but the album differs from others this year that seem bruised by sociopolitical strife in that it isn‚Äôt just an emotional response to the spiritual bummer accompanying our rapid descent into cultural warfare. It‚Äôs also a provocation for the parties responsible. Opener ‚ÄúQuorum‚Äù is a cry for justice: ‚ÄúYou‚Äôve torn vacant stares / You tried to break the quorum.‚Äù ‚ÄúA quorum is the minimum amount of a group of people that needs to be there to make a decision for that decision to be valid,‚Äù Sparhawk explained to The Wire. The president lost the popular vote by 3 million ballots.

In its long stretches of peaceful, eddying drones, Double Negative also resembles New York composer William Basinski‚Äôs Disintegration Loops, another artifact of American decay. Basinski famously finished the project, which documents the sound of 20-year-old tape recordings crumbling, on the morning of 9/11. Both records‚Äô crash into sad, gorgeous rot brush against the pulse of the times. But where 2001 fell from bullish comfort to paranoiac warmongering, 2018 has seen America gnawing away at itself, so Low‚Äôs vision is decidedly more disquieting. For every moment of calm ‚Äî see: the chant that closes ‚ÄúDancing and Blood‚Äù or the lengthy drone that consumes ‚ÄúAlways Up‚Äù two-thirds in ‚Äî there‚Äôs something terrifying lying in wait. The thicket of static and howling voices comprising the meat of ‚ÄúThe Son, the Sun‚Äù must be what Dante Alighieri heard when he imagined Hell. ‚ÄúQuorum‚Äù traps a beautiful melody behind a wall of clattering noise in the same way that Ben Frost records whittle pretty sounds down to jagged things, like shivs.

Double Negative recasts Sparhawk and Parker‚Äôs light, ephemeral approach to melody as something hard and steely. Album highlight ‚ÄúTempest‚Äù has a vocal that is both pleading and nearly unintelligible, like someone using April Base‚Äôs trademark robot harmony tech without laying clean vocals on top. Mimi‚Äôs voice sputters through ‚ÄúDancing and Blood‚Äù like a flickering hologram. Bassist Steve Garrington is actually the MVP of this album; his role as arbiter of the band‚Äôs keyboards and low end is crucial to the guttural reaches of the new songs. A few of the eerie, sustained vocal melodies throughout Double Negative are actually samples of Sparhawk and Parker‚Äôs voices, meaning there‚Äôs electronics at play even in the human elements of the album. What‚Äôs astounding about the radical changes in gear and method is that, beneath the static, Low still sounds like Low. Melodies still bob and drift like fish lounging in a tank. Alan‚Äôs and Mimi‚Äôs voices still seem made expressly for each other, even processed to a point of technological singularity. The notes everyone plays and sings still root themselves in Western rock and folk traditions.

There‚Äôs a cinematic feel to Double Negative‚Äôs unsettling machine blues. The balance of serenity and calamity here plays a kindred spirit to Alfonso Cuar√≥n‚Äôs white knuckle sci-fi thriller Gravity (and Steven Price‚Äôs Academy Award‚Äìwinning score), where Sandra Bullock plays an astronaut whose failed mission to repair the Hubble telescope destroys her ship and leaves her floating in space and, eventually, hurtling back to Earth. Double Negative is front-loaded with all of the most alien, forbidding sounds; the album is sequenced as a slow drift from parts unknown back to familiar territory. The late album gems ‚ÄúDancing and Fire,‚Äù ‚ÄúPoor Sucker,‚Äù and ‚ÄúRome (Always in the Dark)‚Äù could reasonably fit on any of the last three Low albums, but here, situated at the end of a dizzying program of augmented voices and whirring noises, they feel like the grizzled perseverance at the bottom of a moment of distress. ‚ÄúBefore it falls into total disarray,‚Äù Sparhawk sings on the closer, ‚Äúyou‚Äôll have to learn to live a different way.‚Äù It‚Äôs the closest thing to a pop song the album is willing to muster, a hopeful, ascending melody assembled out of squelching, flatulent noises that seems to say, in its lyrics and composition, that unpleasantness is best used as kindling, as fuel to get to a better place.

content: Perhaps you were already under the assumption that the deepest love you‚Äôve ever felt was the love you felt in high school: be it for your first boyfriend or girlfriend, or for someone in *NSYNC. It is true that teenagers feel their feelings with deranged inte‚Ä¶ [+2674 chars]
description: Teen brains are still developing, but that doesn‚Äôt mean they can‚Äôt FEEL.
title: Teenagers Do Too Know What Real Love Is
fulltext:
Photo: Carl Iwasaki/Getty Images/The LIFE Picture Co

Perhaps you were already under the assumption that the deepest love you‚Äôve ever felt was the love you felt in high school: be it for your first boyfriend or girlfriend, or for someone in *NSYNC. It is true that teenagers feel their feelings with deranged intensity, which is the only explanation for the time I gave a crush my phone number by creating a secret program in his TI-83 graphing calculator. Never again (hopefully) will you feel that you will die if you don‚Äôt spend every waking second talking to or at least looking at the object of your desire.

Still, a recent Reddit r/relationships thread presented the world‚Äôs lovelorn teens with a challenge: If the human brain doesn‚Äôt finish developing until one‚Äôs mid-20s, is it really possible for anyone younger to truly comprehend the meaning of love?

The question was posed by a 23-year-old woman whose 23-year-old boyfriend of more than a year (‚ÄúAndy‚Äù) told her it‚Äôs ‚Äútoo soon‚Äù to know if he loves her because of their undeveloped brains. I agree that his brain is underdeveloped, but the commenters were polarized. User princessmorbux took the boyfriend‚Äôs side, writing: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not going to lie, my concept of love was completely different at 23 than 29. He‚Äôs not entirely wrong.‚Äù User ConsistentCheesecake, however, was not having it: ‚ÄúWow your boyfriend sounds like a pretentious, insufferable person. Over a year and he can‚Äôt say he loves you? DEAL BREAKER. Plus his argument is insanely stupid anyway.‚Äù

So who‚Äôs right? According to Dean Burnett, a neuroscientist and author of the international best sellers Idiot Brain and Happy Brain, it‚Äôs the girlfriend, along with princessmorbux et al. (Duh.) Burnett points out that while it‚Äôs true that the brain continues to develop well into our 20s, that doesn‚Äôt mean it can‚Äôt do anything properly before that point: ‚ÄúWhen we hit our teens, our brains are still developing, but they‚Äôre not necessarily acquiring new abilities or information. Instead, they‚Äôre sorting out what they‚Äôve already accumulated, and making things more efficient,‚Äù he writes. By one‚Äôs late teens (and certainly by the age of 23, ANDY), the brain is maturing and learning to make important connections.

Furthermore, what needs the most development in one‚Äôs teens and 20s aren‚Äôt the basic, instinctive processes like fear, affection, and love, but more complex, prefrontal-cortex-based functions. What makes our teen years (and early 20s) so emotionally overwhelming, says Burnett, is actually the fact that we can feel all those superintense feelings, but don‚Äôt yet have all the rational thought processes in place to control them.

This may seem like bad news for the original poster, but it only feels that way now. In an update to her post, she informed the Reddit community that she and Andy broke up mere days later, during a discussion in which he had the unbelievable nerve to pull the ‚ÄúI love you, but I‚Äôm not in love with you‚Äù card. Good riddance!!
